sen.j: 東大寺（とうだいじ）は、奈良県奈良市雑司町にある華厳宗大本山の仏教寺院である。
sen.e: Todai-ji is the main temple of the Kegon sect of Buddhism in Zoshi-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture in Japan.

sen.j: 「金光明四天王護国之寺」（こんこうみょうしてんのうごこくのてら）ともいい、奈良時代（8世紀）に聖武天皇が国力を尽くして建立した寺である。
sen.e: The temple is also called 'Konkomyo shitenno gokoku no tera' and it was erected by the Emperor Shomu using the national power in the Nara period (eighth century).

sen.e: The principal image there is Birushana Buddha known as 'the Todai-ji rushanabutsuzo' and Kaizan (the first Betto) was Roben Sojo.

sen.j: 奈良時代には中心堂宇の大仏殿（金堂）のほか、東西2つの七重塔（推定高さ約100メートル）を含む大伽藍が整備されたが、中世以降、2度の兵火で多くの建物を焼失した。
sen.e: In the Nara period, there was a large Buddhist temple with two Nanajunoto (Seven-story Pagodas; estimated height of 100m) on the east and the west as well as the Great Buddha Hall (Kon-do Hall) in the center but most of the buildings were burned in two fires caused by wars after the Kamakura period.

In the Nara period, there was a large Buddhist temple including the Great Buddha Hall (Kon-do Hall) at the center and two Nanajunoto (seven-story pagodas; estimated height 100m) on the east and the west sides, but most of the buildings were burned in two fires caused by wars after the Kamakura period.

In the Nara period, there was a large Buddhist temple including the Great Buddha Hall (Kon-do Hall) at the center and two Nanajunoto (seven-story pagodas; estimated height 100m) on the east and the west sides, but most of the buildings were burned in two fires caused by wars after the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 現存する大仏は、台座などの一部に当初の部分を残すのみであり、現存する大仏殿は江戸時代、18世紀初頭の再建で、創建当時の堂に比べ、間口が3分の2に縮小されている。
sen.e: The existing Great Buddha only has a part of the foundation remaining from the original but the current Great Buddha Hall was reconstructed in the Edo Period, early 18th century; compared to the original hall, it is 30% smaller than the its predecessor.

The existing Great Buddha's pedastal retains only one part from the original, and the current Great Buddha Hall was reconstructed in the Edo Period, early 18th century; it is just two-thirds the size of the original hall.

The existing Great Buddha's pedestal retains only one part from the original, and the current Great Buddha Hall was reconstructed in the Edo Period, early 18th century; it is just two-thirds the size of the original hall.
sen.cmt: スペルミスを訂正しました（pedastal→pedestal）。

sen.j: 「大仏さん」の寺として、古代から現代に至るまで広い信仰を集め、日本の文化に多大な影響を与えてきた寺院であり、聖武天皇が当時の日本の60余か国に建立させた国分寺の本山にあたる「総国分寺」と位置づけられた。
sen.e: As the temple of the 'Daibutsu-san' (Mr Big Buddha), the temple has attracted many religious people since ancient times to the present day and this had a great affect on Japanese culture; it was placed as 'So-Kokubunji', the head temple of the Kokubun-ji Temples that the Emperor Shomu ordered to build in 60 Provinces of Japan at that time.

sen.j: 東大寺の起源は大仏造立よりやや古く、8世紀前半には大仏殿の東方、若草山麓に前身寺院が建てられていた。
sen.e: The predecessor of the Todai-ji Temple was slightly older than the construction of the Great Buddha and by the first half of the eighth century, the predecessor temple was built in the east of the Great Buddha Hall, on the foot of Mt. Wakakusa.

The predecessor of Todai-ji Temple dates back to slightly before construction of the Great Buddha, and by the first half of the eighth century the preceeding temple had been built to the east of the Great Buddha Hall, at the foot of Mt. Wakakusa.

sen.cmt: スペルミスを訂正しました（preceeding→preceding）。

sen.j: 東大寺の記録である『東大寺要録』によれば、天平5年（733年）、若草山麓に創建された金鐘寺（または金鍾寺（こんしゅじ））が東大寺の起源であるとされる。
sen.e: According to the "Todai-ji Yoroku" (The Digest Record of Todai-ji Temple), the Konshu-ji Temple (金鐘寺 or 金鍾寺) built on the foot of Mt. Wakakusa in 733 was the predecessor of the Todai-ji Temple.
According to the "Todai-ji Yoroku" (The Digest Record of Todai-ji Temple), Konshu-ji Temple (金鐘寺 or 金鍾寺) built at the foot of Mt. Wakakusa in 733 was the predecessor of the Todai-ji Temple.
According to the "Todai-ji Yoroku" (The Digest Record of Todai-ji Temple), Konshu-ji Temple (金鐘寺 or 金鍾寺) built at the foot of Mt. Wakakusa in 733 was the predecessor of the Todai-ji Temple.

sen.j: 一方、正史『続日本紀』によれば、神亀5年（728年）、第45代の天皇である聖武天皇と光明皇后が幼くして亡くなった皇子の菩提のため、若草山麓に「山房」を設け、9人の僧を住まわせたことが知られ、これが金鐘寺の前身と見られる。
sen.e: On the other hand, according to the official history book "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), in 728, the 45th emperor, Emperor Shomu and Empress Komyo set up a 'San-so' (mountain retreat) on the foot of Mt. Wakakusa to pray to Buddha for the happiness of the prince who died young and they made nine priests live there; and this is said to be the predecessor of the Konshu-ji Temple.

On the other hand, according to the official history book "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), in 728, the 45th emperor, Emperor Shomu and Empress Komyo set up a 'San-so' (mountain retreat) at the foot of Mt. Wakakusa to pray to Buddha for the happiness of the prince who died young, and they made nine priests live there; this is said to be the predecessor of the Konshu-ji Temple.

Wakakusa to pray to Buddha for the happiness of the prince who died young, and they made nine priests live there; this is said to be the predecessor of the Konshu-ji Temple.

sen.j: 金鐘寺には、8世紀半ばには羂索堂、千手堂が存在したことが記録から知られ、このうち羂索堂は現在の法華堂（＝三月堂、本尊は不空羂索観音）を指すと見られる。
sen.e: From records, it is known that, by the mid eighth century, the Kinshu-ji Temple had the Kensaku-do Hall and the Senju-do Hall and the Kensaku-do Hall was believed to be the predecessor of the current Hokke-do Hall (= Sangatsu-do Hall, the principal image there is the Fukukenjaku Kannon (Amoghapasa [manifestation of Amalokitesvara]).

From records it is known that by the mid eighth century, Kensaku-do Hall and the Senju-do Hall were already built in Kinshu-ji Temple, and the Kensaku-do Hall is believed to be the predecessor of the current Hokke-do Hall (= Sangatsu-do Hall; the principal image there is the Fukukenjaku Kannon (Amoghapasa [manifestation of Amalokitesvara]).

sen.j: 天平13年（741年）には国分寺建立の詔（みことのり）が発せられ、これを受けて翌天平14年（742年）、金鐘寺は大和国の国分寺と定められ、寺名は金光明寺と改められた。
sen.e: In 741, an imperial edict for the establishment of the Kokubun-ji Temples was issued and in 742, the Konshu-ji Temple was included as a Kokubun-ji Temple; the name of the temple was changed to Kinkomyo-ji.

sen.j: 大仏の鋳造が始まったのは天平19年（747年）で、この頃から「東大寺」の寺号が用いられるようになったと思われる。
sen.e: The construction of the Great Buddha began around 747 and it is believed that the Jigo (temple name) of 'Todai-ji' also began to be used from that time.

sen.j: なお、東大寺建設のための役所である「造東大寺司」が史料に見えるのは天平20年（748年）が最初である。
sen.e: The name of the office for the construction of the Todai-ji Temple 'Zou Todai-ji Shi' first appeared in historical records in 748.

sen.j: 聖武天皇が大仏造立の詔（みことのり）を発したのはそれより前の天平15年（743年）である。
sen.e: In 743, the Emperor Shomu issued the edict to construct the Great Buddha proceding that.
Prior to this, in 743, Emperor Shomu issued an edict to construct the Great Buddha.

sen.j: 当時、都は恭仁京（くにのみや 京都府相楽郡加茂町 (京都府)）に移されていたが、天皇は恭仁京の北東に位置する紫香楽宮（しがらきのみや 現・滋賀県甲賀市信楽町）におり、大仏造立もここで始められた。
sen.e: At that time, the capital was moved to the Kuni-kyo (Kamo-cho, Soraku District, Kyoto Prefecture) but the Emperor was residing at the Shigaraki no Miya Palace (current Shigaraki-cho, Koga City, Shiga Prefecture) and the construction of the Great Buddha also began from there.

At that time, the capital was moved to Kuni-kyo (Kamo-cho, Soraku District, Kyoto Prefecture) but the Emperor was residing at Shigaraki no Miya Palace (current Shigaraki-cho, Koga City, Shiga Prefecture) and construction of the Great Buddha also began there.

sen.j: 聖武天皇は短期間に遷都を繰り返したが、2年後の天平17年（745年）、都が平城京に戻るとともに大仏造立も現在の東大寺の地であらためて行われることになった。
sen.e: The Emperor Shomu repeatedly transferred the capital within a short time but in 745, he moved it back to the Heijo-kyo and he decided to restart the construction of the Great Buddha in the current place of the Todai-ji Temple.

The Emperor Shomu repeatedly transferred the capital within a short period, but in 745 he moved it back to Heijo-kyo and decided to restart construction of the Great Buddha in the current location of Todai-ji Temple.

sen.j: この大事業を推進するには幅広い民衆の支持が必要であったため、朝廷から弾圧されていた行基を大僧正として迎え、協力を得た。
sen.e: To promote this huge project, the Emperor needed wide support from the people, so he appointed Gyoki who was oppressed by the Imperial Court as the Daisojo (High Priest) and asked for his co-operation.

To promote this huge project the Emperor needed wide support from the people, so he appointed Gyoki, who was oppressed by the Imperial Court, as the Daisojo (High Priest) and asked for his co-operation.

sen.j: 難工事の末、大仏の鋳造が終了し、天竺（インド）出身の僧・菩提僊那を導師として大仏開眼会（かいげんえ）が挙行されたのは天平勝宝4年（752年）のことであった。
sen.e: After a long and hard construction, the casting of the Great Buddha was completed and it was in 752 when the Kaigan-e (ceremony of "kaigan", enshrining newly built Buddhist image and to put a spirit as opening eyes to Buddhism) was conducted by the Priest from India Bodai Senna as the ceremony leader.

After a long and hard construction, the casting of the Great Buddha was completed and in 752 the Kaigan-e (ceremony of "kaigan", to enshrine a newly built Buddhist image and to put in a spirit to open eyes to Buddhism) was conducted with the Priest from India Bodai Senna as the ceremony leader.

sen.cmt: Priest→priest（固有名詞扱いではなく大文字にする必要がないため小文字にしました。）

sen.j: そして、大仏鋳造が終わってから大仏殿の建設工事が始められ、竣工したのは天平宝字2年（758年）のことであった。
sen.e: After the completion of the casting of the Great Buddha, the construction work for the Great Buddha Hall started; it was in 758 when the Hall construction was completed.
After completion of the casting of the Great Buddha, the construction work for the Great Buddha Hall started; the hall construction was completed in 758.

sen.j: 東大寺では大仏創建に力のあった良弁、聖武天皇、行基、菩提僊那を「四聖（ししょう）」と呼んでいる。
sen.e: At the Todai-ji Temple, the four people: Roben, the Emperor Shomu, Gyoki and Bodai Senna are called 'Shisho' (The Holy Four).

tit.e: The Todai-ji Temple and TACHIBANA no Naramaro
The Todai-ji Temple and TACHIBANA no Naramaro
The Todai-ji Temple and TACHIBANA no Naramaro

sen.j: 大仏造立・大仏殿建立のような大規模な建設工事は国費を浪費させ、日本の財政事情を悪化させるという、聖武天皇の思惑とは程遠い事実を突き付けた。
sen.e: The large construction projects like those of the Great Buddha and of the Great Buddha Hall showed the fact that the Emperor Shomu had never thought about, that they would cost the country a large sum of money and worsen the nation's financial affairs.

The large construction projects like those of the Great Buddha and of the Great Buddha Hall showed that Emperor Shomu never thought about the large sums of money they would cost the country and how this would worsen the nation's financial affairs.

The large construction projects like those of the Great Buddha and of the Great Buddha Hall showed that Emperor Shomu never thought about the large sums of money they would cost the country and how this would worsen the nation's financial affairs.

sen.j: 実際に、貴族や寺院が富み栄える一方、農民層の負担が激増し、平城京内では浮浪者や餓死者が後を絶たず、租庸調の税制も崩壊寸前になる地方も出るなど、律令政治の大きな矛盾点を浮き彫りにした。
sen.e: In reality, while the nobles and temples became wealthy, the financial burden on the peasantry; in the Heijo-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Nara), many became homeless and died from starvation and in some regions, the Soyocho tax system almost collapsed, that showed a wide inconsistency of the government under the Ritsuryo codes.

In reality, while the nobility and temples became wealthy, an increasing financial burden was placed on the peasantry; in Heijo-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Nara), many became homeless and died from starvation and in some regions the Soyocho tax system almost collapsed, showing the wide inconsistency of the government under the Ritsuryo codes.

In reality, while the nobility and temples became wealthy, an increasing financial burden was placed on the peasantry; in Heijo-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Nara), many became homeless and died from starvation and in some regions the Soyocho tax system almost collapsed, showing the wide inconsistency of the government under the Ritsuryo codes.

sen.j: 天平勝宝8年（756年）5月2日、聖武太上天皇が死去する。
sen.e: On June 8, 756, the Emperor Shomu (the retired Emperor Shomu at that time) died.
On June 8, 756, Emperor Shomu (the retired Emperor Shomu at that time) died.
On June 8, 756, Emperor Shomu (the retired Emperor Shomu at that time) died.

sen.j: その年の7月に起こったのが、橘奈良麻呂の乱である。
sen.e: In August, the Revolt of TACHIBANA no Naramaro occurred.
The Revolt of TACHIBANA no Naramaro occurred in August.
The Revolt of TACHIBANA no Naramaro occurred in August of the same year.
sen.cmt: 「その年の」が訳抜けでしたので訳を追加しました。

sen.j: 7月4日に逮捕された橘奈良麻呂は、藤原永手の聴取に対して「東大寺などを造営し人民が辛苦している。政治が無道だから反乱を企てた」と謀反を白状した。
sen.e: When TACHIBANA no Naramaro was arrested on August 8, to FUJIWARA no Nagate, he said 'Because of the construction such as the Todai-ji Temple, many people are suffering. Because the government is outrageous, I plotted a rebellion'.

When TACHIBANA no Naramaro was arrested on August 8, he said to FUJIWARA no Nagate "Many people are suffering because of the construction work such as Todai-ji Temple. I plotted a rebellion because the government is outrageous."

When TACHIBANA no Naramaro was arrested on August 8, he said to FUJIWARA no Nagate "Many people are suffering because of the construction work such as Todai-ji Temple. I plotted a rebellion because the government is outrageous."

sen.j: ここで、永手は、「そもそも東大寺の建立が始まったのは、そなたの父（橘諸兄）の時代である。その口でとやかく言われる筋合いは無いし、それ以前にそなたとは何の因果もないはずだ」と反論したため、奈良麻呂は返答に詰まったと言う。
sen.e: Answering the question, Nagate said 'The construction of Todai-ji Temple started when your father (TACHIBANA no Moroe) was around. So, it is none of your business. Before that, it is nothing do with you', and Naramaro was stuck for an answer.

Nagate replied "The construction of Todai-ji Temple started when your father (TACHIBANA no Moroe) was around so it is none of your business. You have no reason to grumble, it is nothing do with you," and Naramaro was stuck for an answer.

Nagate replied "The construction of Todai-ji Temple started when your father (TACHIBANA no Moroe) was around so it is none of your business. You have no reason to grumble, it is nothing to do with you," and Naramaro was stuck for an answer.
sen.cmt: "nothing do with→nothing to do withto"が訳抜けでしたので訳を挿入しました。

sen.j: 橘奈良麻呂の乱は計画性に乏しく、軽率と言えば、軽率ではあった。
sen.e: The revolt of TACHIBANA no Naramaro was poorly planned so it was ill-advised in a way.
The revolt of TACHIBANA no Naramaro was poorly planned so it can be described as ill-advised.
The revolt of TACHIBANA no Naramaro was poorly planned so it can be described as ill-advised.

sen.j: しかしながら、反乱の口実にまで東大寺が利用された、ということは、東大寺建立自体が、天皇の理想を実現させる、ただそれだけのために実際の労働状況や財政事情等の問題点を度外視した途方もない、一大プロジェクトであったことをも白日の下にさらした。
sen.e: However, the fact that Todai-ji Temple was used even as an excuse for a rebellion means that construction of the Todai-ji Temple was a large project aiming only to realize the Emperor's wish and totally neglected other issues such as actual working conditions and financial affairs.

However, the fact that Todai-ji Temple was even used as an excuse for a rebellion shows that construction of Todai-ji Temple was a large project aiming only to realize the Emperor's wish while totally neglecting other issues such as actual working conditions and financial affairs.

tit.j: 奈良時代・平安時代の東大寺
tit.e: Todai-ji Temple in the Nara and Heian Periods
Todai-ji Temple in the Nara and Heian Periods
Todai-ji Temple in the Nara and Heian Periods

sen.j: 奈良時代の東大寺の伽藍は、南大門、中門、金堂（大仏殿）、講堂が南北方向に一直線に並び、講堂の北側には東・北・西に「コ」の字形に並ぶ僧房（僧の居所）、僧房の東には食堂（じきどう）があり、南大門-中門間の左右には東西2基の七重塔（高さ約100メートルと推定される）が回廊に囲まれて建っていた。
sen.e: In the temple of Todai-ji in the Nara Period, the Nandai-mon Gate, Chumon Gate, Kon-do Hall (the Great Buddha Hall) and the Kodo Hall were all in a line in a north and south direction and on the north side of the Kodo Hall, there were the priests' living quarters in the U-shape in the east, north and west; and on the left and right sides between the Nandai-mon Gate and Chumon Gate, there were two sets (east and west) of Nanajunoto (Seven-story Pagodas, approximately 100m tall) and corridors surrounding them.

In the temple of Todai-ji in the Nara Period, Nandai-mon Gate, Chumon Gate, Kon-do Hall (the Great Buddha Hall) and Kodo Hall were all in a line in a north to south direction, and on the north side of the Kodo Hall the priests' living quarters were layed out in a U-shape to the east, north and west; and on the left and right sides between the Nandai-mon Gate and Chumon Gate, there were two sets (east and west) of Nanajunoto (seven-story pagodas, approximately 100m tall) and corridors surrounding them.

In the temple of Todai-ji in the Nara Period, Nandai-mon Gate, Chumon Gate, Kon-do Hall (the Great Buddha Hall) and Kodo Hall were all in a line in a north to south direction, and on the north side of the Kodo Hall the priests' living quarters were layed out in a U-shape to the east, north and west; and on the left and right sides between the Nandai-mon Gate and Chumon Gate, there were two sets (east and west) of Nanajunoto (seven-story pagodas, approximately 100m tall) and corridors surrounding them.

sen.j: 天平17年（745年）の起工から、伽藍が一通り完成するまでには40年近い時間を要している。
sen.e: It took almost 40 years from the beginning of construction to the completion of the whole temple.
It took almost 40 years from the beginning of construction in 745 to the completion of the whole temple.
It took almost 40 years from the beginning of construction in 745 to the completion of the whole temple.

sen.j: 奈良時代のいわゆる南都六宗（華厳宗、法相宗、律宗、三論宗、成実宗、倶舎宗）は「宗派」というよりは「学派」に近いもので、日本仏教で「宗派」という概念が確立したのは中世以後のことである。
sen.e: In the Nara Period, so-called 'Nanto Rokushu' (Six sects of Buddhism: Kegon, Hosso, Tutsu, Sanron, Jojitsu and Kusha) were more like 'school sects' rather than 'religious sects' and the time when the concept of the 'religious sects' were established was after the medieval period.

In the Nara Period, the so-called 'Nanto Rokushu' (Six sects of Buddhism: Kegon, Hosso, Tutsu, Sanron, Jojitsu and Kusha) were more like 'school sects' rather than 'religious sects;' the concept of 'religious sects' was established after the medieval period.

In the Nara Period, the so-called 'Nanto Rokushu' (Six sects of Buddhism: Kegon, Hosso, Tutsu, Sanron, Jojitsu and Kusha) were more like 'school sects' rather than 'religious sects;' the concept of 'religious sects' was established after the medieval period.

sen.j: そのため、寺院では複数の宗派を兼学することが普通であった。
sen.e: Therefore, at that time, it was normal to study a few religious sects at a temple.
Therefore, at that time, it was normal to study a few different religious sects at the same temple.
Therefore, at that time, it was normal to study a few different religious sects at the same temple.

sen.j: 東大寺の場合、近代以降は所属宗派を明示する必要から華厳宗を名乗るが、奈良時代には「六宗兼学の寺」とされ、大仏殿内には各宗の経論を納めた「六宗厨子」があった。
sen.e: As for Todai-ji Temple, since the Meiji Period, temples have been required to clarify their religious sects and Todai-ji Temple is in the Kegon sect; but in the Nara Period, Todai-ji was a 'Rokushu Kengaku no tera' (Temple of syncretic study of the six sects of Buddhist learning) and inside the Great Buddha Hall, there was a 'Rokushu-zushi' (a cupboard-like case with double doors) in which textbooks of all the sects were kept.

As for Todai-ji Temple, since the Meiji Period, temples have been required to clarify their religious sects and Todai-ji Temple is in the Kegon sect; but in the Nara Period, Todai-ji was a 'Rokushu Kengaku no tera' (Temple of syncretic study of the six sects of Buddhist learning) and inside the Great Buddha Hall, there was a 'Rokushu-zushi' (a cupboard-like case with double doors) in which textbooks of all the sects were kept.

As for Todai-ji Temple, since the Meiji Period, temples have been required to clarify their religious sects and Todai-ji Temple is in the Kegon sect; but in the Nara Period, Todai-ji was a 'Rokushu Kengaku no tera' (Temple of syncretic study of the six sects of Buddhist learning) and inside the Great Buddha Hall, there was a 'Rokushu-zushi' (a cupboard-like case with double doors) in which textbooks of all the sects were kept.

sen.j: 平安時代には空海によって寺内に真言院が開かれ、空海が伝えた真言宗、最澄が伝えた天台宗をも加えて「八宗兼学の寺」とされた。
sen.e: In the Nara Period, Kukai opened the Shingon sect within the Temple and in the Heian Period, together with the Tendai-shu sect that Saicho brought, Todai-ji was a 'Hasshu Kengaku no tera' (Temple of syncretic study of eight sects of Buddhist learning).

In the Nara Period, Kukai opened the Shingon sect within the temple and in the Heian Period, together with the Tendai-shu sect brought by Saicho, Todai-ji became a 'Hasshu Kengaku no tera' (Temple of syncretic study of eight sects of Buddhist learning).

In the Nara Period, Kukai opened the Shingon sect within the temple and in the Heian Period, together with the Tendai-shu sect brought by Saicho, Todai-ji became a 'Hasshu Kengaku no tera' (Temple of syncretic study of eight sects of Buddhist learning).

sen.j: また、平安時代に入ると、桓武天皇の南都仏教抑圧策により「造東大寺所」が廃止されるなどの圧迫を受け、また講堂と三面僧房が失火で、西塔が落雷で焼失したり、暴風雨で南大門、鐘楼が倒壊したりといった事件が起こるが、後に皇族・貴族の崇敬を受けて黒田庄に代表される多数の荘園を寄進されたり、開発した。
sen.e: In the Heian Period, Todai-ji was affected by the Emperor Kanmu's Nanto Buddhism Oppression Plan and due to the plan, the Office of Todai-ji Temple Construction was abolished and there were incidents such as the Kodo Hall and Sanmen Sobo (priests and monks dormitories constructed to the north, east and west of the Kodo Hall) being burnt from an accidental fire, Saito (Western Tower) being hit by lightening, the Nandai-mon Gate and the Shoro (Bell Tower) being broken in a storm; but later on, from reverence, the Imperial family and nobility donated private estates including the Kuroda-no-sho and the Todai-ji Temple developed them.
sen.cmt: 「造東大寺所」は「造東大寺司」は同じでしょうか？ご確認ください。
sen.e: In the Heian Period, Todai-ji was affected by the Emperor Kanmu's Nanto Buddhism Oppression Plan, and due to the plan the Office of Todai-ji Temple Construction was abolished, and there were incidents such as the Kodo Hall and Sanmen Sobo (priests and monks dormitories constructed to the north, east and west of the Kodo Hall) being burnt from an accidental fire, the Saito (Western Tower) being hit by lightening, and the Nandai-mon Gate and the Shoro (Bell Tower) being broken in a storm; but later on, from reverence, the Imperial family and nobility donated private estates including the Kuroda-no-sho and Todai-ji Temple developed them.

In the Heian Period, Todai-ji was affected by the Emperor Kanmu's Nanto Buddhism Oppression Plan, and due to the plan the Office of Todai-ji Temple Construction was abolished, and there were incidents such as the Kodo Hall and Sanmen Sobo (priests and monks dormitories constructed to the north, east and west of the Kodo Hall) being burnt from an accidental fire, the Saito (Western Tower) being hit by lightening, and the Nandai-mon Gate and the Shoro (Bell Tower) being broken in a storm; but later on, from reverence, the Imperial family and nobility donated private estates including the Kuroda-no-sho and Todai-ji Temple developed them.

sen.j: やがて、奈良の有力権門として内外に知られるようになり、多数の僧兵を抱え、興福寺などと度々強訴を行っている。
sen.e: The Todai-ji Temple became well-known inside and outside the region as an influential group in Nara; holding many warrior monks, Todai-ji Temple directly petitioned with other temples such as Kofuku-ji.
Todai-ji Temple became well-known inside and outside the region as an influential group in Nara; holding many warrior monks, Todai-ji Temple directly petitioned other temples such as Kofuku-ji.

tit.e: After the Medieval Period (After the Kamakura and Muromachi Periods in Japan)
After the Medieval Period (after the Kamakura and Muromachi Periods)
After the Medieval Period (after the Kamakura and Muromachi Periods)

sen.j: 東大寺は、近隣の興福寺とともに治承4年12月28日（1181年1月15日）の平重衡の兵火で壊滅的な打撃（南都焼討）を受け、大仏殿をはじめとする多くの堂塔を失った。
sen.e: Todai-ji Temple, together with its neighbor Kofuku-ji Temple, suffered a devastating damage from a fire caused by TAIRA no Shigehira (Nanto Yakiuchi [the Incident of Heishi's army setting fire to the temples in Nanto]) on January 15, 1181 and lost many buildings including the Great Buddha Hall.

Todai-ji Temple, together with its neighbor Kofuku-ji Temple, suffered devastating damage from a fire caused by TAIRA no Shigehira (Nanto Yakiuchi [the Incident of Heishi's army setting fire to the temples in Nanto]) on January 15, 1181 and lost many buildings including the Great Buddha Hall.

Todai-ji Temple, together with its neighbor Kofuku-ji Temple, suffered devastating damage from a fire caused by TAIRA no Shigehira (Nanto Yakiuchi [the Incident of Heishi's army setting fire to the temples in Nanto]) on January 15, 1181 and lost many buildings including the Great Buddha Hall.

sen.j: この時、大勧進職に任命され、大仏や諸堂の再興に当たったのが当時61歳の僧・俊乗坊重源であった。
sen.e: A 61-year old priest Chogen SHUNJOBO was appointed in the position of Daikanjin (priest to collect contributions) toward reconstruction of the Great Buddha and the Halls.
A 61-year old priest Chogen SHUNJOBO was appointed to the position of Daikanjin (priest to collect contributions) toward reconstruction of the Great Buddha and the Halls.
A 61-year old priest Chogen SHUNJOBO was appointed to the position of Daikanjin (priest to collect contributions) toward reconstruction of the Great Buddha and the Halls.

sen.j: 重源の精力的な活動により、文治元年（1185年）には後白河法皇らの列席のもと、大仏開眼法要が行われ、建久元年（1190年）には、再建大仏殿が完成、源頼朝らの列席のもと、落慶法要が営まれた。
sen.e: Due to Chogen's great efforts, the Kaigen-hoyo (ceremony of "kaigan", enshrining newly built Buddhist image and to put a spirit as opening eyes to Buddhism) was conducted in the presence of people such as Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa being there in 1185; in 1190, the reconstruction of the Great Buddha Hall was completed and the opening ceremony was conducted in the presence of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo and others.

sen.j: その後、戦国時代の永禄10年10月10日（1567年11月10日）、三好・松永の戦いの兵火により、大仏殿を含む東大寺の主要堂塔はまたも焼失した（東大寺大仏殿の戦い参照）。
sen.e: However, on November 10, 1567 of the Sengoku Period (the Warring States Period), a fire caused by the Battle of Miyoshi and Matsunaga burnt the main buildings of Todai-ji Temple including the Great Buddha Hall, again (See "warrior clashes at the Great Buddha Hall of Todai-ji temple").

However, on November 10, 1567 of the Sengoku Period (the Warring States Period), there was a fire caused by the Battle of Miyoshi and Matsunaga, and the main buildings of Todai-ji Temple including the Great Buddha Hall were again burned. (See "warrior clashes at the Great Buddha Hall of Todai-ji temple").

sen.j: 仮堂が建てられたが慶長15年（1610年）の暴風で倒壊し大仏は露座のまま放置された。
sen.e: A temporary Hall was built but was broken down due to strong winds in 1610; the Great Buddha was left sitting down in a place without a roof.
A temporary Hall was built but collapsed due to strong winds in 1610, and the Great Buddha was left sitting in the open air.

sen.cmt: 他と表記を一致させるためHall->hallとしました。

sen.j: その後の大仏の修理は元禄4年（1691年）に完成し、再建大仏殿は公慶上人（1648年-1705年）の尽力や、将軍徳川綱吉や母の桂昌院をはじめ多くの人々による寄進が行われた結果、宝永6年（1709年）に完成した。
sen.e: The repair of the Great Buddha was completed in 1691; with the efforts of Kokei Shonin (1648 - 1705) and donations by Shogun Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA, his mother Keishoin and others, the reconstruction of the Great Buddha Hall was completed in 1709.

sen.j: この3代目の大仏殿（現存）は、高さと奥行きは天平時代とほぼ同じだが、間口は天平創建時の11間からおよそ3分の2の7間に縮小されている。
sen.e: The third Great Buddha Hall (current one) has the same height and depth but the width is 30% smaller from 20m of the original one to 12.7m.
The third Great Buddha Hall (the current one) has the same height and depth as the original, but the width is 30% smaller, reduced from 20m to 12.7m.

sen.j: また、講堂、食堂、東西の七重塔など近世以降はついに再建されることはなく、今は各建物跡に礎石のみが残されている。
sen.e: The Kodo Hall, Dining Hall and the east and west Nanajunoto (Seven-story pagodas) were not reconstructed after the early-modern times and now only foundation stones are left at the places where they used to be.

The Kodo Hall, Dining Hall and the east and west Nanajunoto (seven-story pagodas) were not reconstructed after early-modern times and now only foundation stones are left at the places where they used to be.

sen.j: 東大寺は1998年に古都奈良の文化財の一部として、国際連合教育科学文化機関より世界遺産に登録されている。
sen.e: The temple was listed as a United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) World Heritage Site and as a part of the cultural property of Ancient Nara in 1998.

sen.j: 毎年1月1日の0時から8時までの間、中門（重要文化財）が開かれ、金堂（大仏殿・国宝）内に無料で入堂できる（通常入堂料：大人500円・小人300円）。
sen.e: On the new year's day every year, the Chumon Gate (Important Cultural Heritage) is open to the public between 12:00am to 8am and people can enter the Kon-do Hall (the Great Buddha Hall: National Treasure) with the admission free (normally 500JPY for an adult and 300JPY for a child).

On New Year's Day every year, the Chumon Gate (Important Cultural Heritage) is open to the public between midnight and 8am, and people can enter the Kon-do Hall (the Great Buddha Hall: National Treasure) with admission free (normally 500 Japanese yen for an adult and 300 yen for a child).

On New Year's Day every year, the Chumon Gate (Important Cultural Heritage) is open to the public between midnight and 8am, and people can enter the Kon-do Hall (the Great Buddha Hall: National Treasure) with admission free (normally 500 Japanese yen for an adult and 300 yen for a child).

sen.j: 参拝は午前7時半から受け付けている。
sen.e: Visiting the Temple to pray is allowed after 7:30am.

sen.j: 平安時代の応和2年（962年）8月に台風で倒壊後、鎌倉時代の正治元年（1199年）に復興されたもの。
sen.e: The current Gate was reconstructed in the Kamakura Period in 1199 after being broken by a typhoon in September, 962 in the Heian Period.

sen.j: 東大寺中興の祖である俊乗坊重源が中国・宋 (王朝)から伝えた建築様式といわれる大仏様（だいぶつよう、天竺様・てんじくようともいう）を採用した建築として著名である。
sen.e: It is famous because it used architecture of the Daibutsu-yo style (Buddhist architecture style also called 'Tenjiku-yo' [Indian style]), that the restorer of Todai-ji Temple Chogen SHUNJOBO is believed to have brought from Sung Dynasty China.

It is famous because it used architecture of the Daibutsu-yo style (Buddhist architecture style also called 'Tenjiku-yo' [Indian style]), that the restorer of Todai-ji Temple Chogen SHUNJOBO is believed to have brought from Sung Dynasty China.

sen.j: 大仏様の特色は、貫 (建築)と呼ばれる、柱を貫通する水平材を多用して構造を堅固にしていること、天井を張らずに構造材をそのまま見せて装飾としていることなどが挙げられる。
sen.e: The characteristics of the Daubitsu-yo style are, for example, using many horizontal braces through vertical posts called Nuki to make the structure solid and showing the construction material as decoration without covering with a ceiling, etc.

sen.e: This theory is different from the traditional 'The Agyo statue had Kaikei and the Ungyo statue had Unkei as the main sculptor' but whatever happened, it would not be wrong to say that Unkei was the executive manager of the whole project.

sen.j: 東大寺は、光明皇后が悲田院や施薬院を設け、日本の社会事業のさきがけとなった寺院であるため今も各種社会事業が行なわれている。
sen.e: Todai-ji is the Temple where the Empress Komyo established Hiden-in and Seyaku-in and became initiatives of social works; so there are many social works done even today.

sen.j: 東大寺福祉療育病院
sen.e: Todai-ji Medical and Educational Center

sen.j: 肢体不自由児施設・東大寺整肢園と重症心身障害児施設・東大寺光明園、及び重症心身障害児者通園施設・華の明から成り、障害を持つ子供たちの療育を行っている。
sen.e: It has 'Todai-ji Seishi En', the center for orthopedically-impaired children, 'Todai-ji Komyo En', the center for severe mentally and physically handicapped children and 'Hananoakari', the day-care center for severe mentally and physically handicapped children; they provides special education for children with disabilities.

sen.j: また、一般の整形外科等の外来や入院手術、リハビリテーションなども行っている。
sen.e: It also provides an out-patient clinic at orthopedics, etc and in-hospital, surgery and rehabilitation services.

sen.e: It used to be on the west of Nandai-mon Gate inside the precincts of the Temple, but it now moved to Misasagi-cho Town.

sen.j: 主として仏教関係図書、仏教美術、古書、古文書、考古資料等を蒐集保存し、一般の閲覧に供している。
sen.e: A collection of mainly Buddhism related books, Buddhist art, old books, ancient documents and archaeological materials are kept and general public have access to them.
